reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s benchmarking move (defining “mostly-great” as ≥50% of “best feasible”), which is moderately central to how the argument operationalizes “no easy eutopia,” but not strictly necessary to the core claim that many futures fall far short due to fragility/fussiness (so centrality < 0.5). Its refutational force is limited because (i) the position explicitly anticipates that intuitively wonderful futures (e.g., Star Trek-like) may be valued far below “near-best” on many views, and uses that as part of the case, and (ii) “best feasible” is defined as a high-percentile of a feasibility distribution, not the theoretical maximum, which directly blunts the critique’s “astronomically high ceiling” framing. Still, the critique correctly notes a real hazard: percentile-normalized thresholds can make ‘mostly-great’ judgments feel counterintuitive and potentially less decision-useful if the distribution has extreme tails. The critique is clear and focused with little dead weight, but contains a significant mischaracterization (treating the benchmark as effectively the absolute ceiling), lowering correctness and strength.
title: Astronomically high value ceilings make intuitive successes count as failures
